review.title: Measuring academic influence: Not all citations are equal
review.abstract: The importance of a research article is routinely measured by counting how many times it has been cited. However, treating all citations with equal weight ignores the wide variety of functions that citations perform. We want to automatically identify the subset of references in a bibliography that have a central academic influence on the citing paper. For this purpose, we examine the effectiveness of a variety of features for determining the academic influence of a citation. By asking authors to identify the key references in their own work, we created a data set in which citations were labeled according to their academic influence. Using automatic feature selection with supervised machine learning, we found a model for predicting academic influence that achieves good performance on this data set using only four features. The best features, among those we evaluated, were those based on the number of times a reference is mentioned in the body of a citing paper. The performance of these features inspired us to design an influence-primed h-index (the hip-index). Unlike the conventional h-index, it weights citations by how many times a reference is mentioned. According to our experiments, the hip-index is a better indicator of researcher performance than the conventional h-index.

sections.text: The importance of a research article is routinely measured by counting how many times it has been cited. To this end, we are investigating the effectiveness of a variety of features to determine the academic impact of a quote. By asking the authors to identify the most important references in their own work, we created a dataset in which quotations were labeled according to their academic influence. Using automatic feature selection with controlled machine learning, we found a model for predicting academic influence that performed well on that dataset, using only four characteristics. The best features among the features we evaluated were features based on the number of times a reference is mentioned in the corpus of an cited work. The performance of these characteristics inspired us to design an influential h-index (the hip index). In contrast to the conventional h-index, quotations are weighted by the number of times a reference is mentioned in a work's corpus.

sections.heading: Defining academic influence
sections.text: What does it mean to say that a reference had more academic influence on a particular quote than another reference? If our goal is to distinguish references by their degree of academic influence, then we need to be precise about the meaning of academic influence. As researchers, we know that some papers have influenced the course of our research more than others, but how can we determine this intuition? A paper written by an evolutionary biologist is likely to have been influenced by Darwin's On the Origin of Species, but we are more interested in the direct influences on the paper. A good research paper contributes to a new idea in the literature. What previous work was the immediate cause, the impetus for this new idea? We believe that this question can best be answered by the authors of the quoting paper, because they are in the best position to decide which of their references are designated as non-influential.

sections.heading: Features for supervised learning
sections.text: We deal with a binary classification problem: in the light of a research paper, we classify their references as either influential or non-influential. The task is to create a model that includes a pair consisting of the work of a particular author (the quoter) and a reference in the given work (the work cited), as input and generate a label (influential or non-influential) as output. Our goal is to create a model that can predict the designations assigned by the authors in our gold standard dataset. Our approach to this task is to use supervised machine learning. For supervised machine learning, we need to generate feature vectors that represent a variety of properties of each paper reference pair. Given a number of manually labeled paper reference function vectors, a learning algorithm can be a model for predicting the designation of a paper reference pair in the test set.We use a standard verified learning algorithm (if these are based on our learning algorithms).

sections.heading: Contextual normalization
sections.text: Many of the above features are sensitive to the length of the quoting paper. < k > The number of occurrences of each reference pair in the whole quoting paper (countsInPaper whole) tends to exceed larger values in a long paper than in a short paper. To predict whether a reference is influential, it is useful to normalize the raw characteristics for a particular paper reference pair by taking into account the range of values in the given quoting paper. & k > Normalization is a form of contextual normalization (Turney, 1993, 1996) in which the quoting paper represents the context of a feature. We normalize all of our characteristics so that their values are in the range [0, 1]. This type of normalization is common practice in data mining as it improves the accuracy of most monitored learning algorithms (Witten, Frank, & Hall, 2011). sections.heading: Gold-standard dataset
sections.text: We believe that the authors of a paper are in the best position to determine whether a particular reference has had a strong impact on their research. In a blog post, we invited authors to help us create a gold standard dataset of designated references. 4 Authors were instructed to fill out an online form. Instructions on the form were as follows: We believe that most papers are based on 1, 2 or 4 essential references. Other references only support the work of authors who have been very influential or inspiring to the core ideas in your paper. We are interested in finding these references automatically, we need your help: Please give us the title of a few of your papers and a list of references that you consider essential.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: One of our main findings is that counting the number of citations in a paper (CountsInPaper overall) is one of the best predictors of how influential a reference is. This is confirmed by an earlier finding by Hou et al. (2011), which stated: "The citation frequency of individual articles in other papers measures their scientific contribution more fairly than mere presence in reference lists." Alternatively, we can count the number of paragraphs in which a paper is cited (CountsInPaper secNum). We believe that weighting citations based on these characteristics (e.g. CountsInPaper overall) would yield more robust results. It should also be used in tracking follow-up papers or recommending research papers. We have also shown that we can combine the citation frequency (CountsInPaper overall) and the semantic relationship between a reference and the cited work to derive a superior classifier.

metadata.abstractText: The importance of a research article is routinely measured by counting how many times it has been cited. However, treating all citations with equal weight ignores the wide variety of functions that citations perform. We want to automatically identify the subset of references in a bibliography that have a central academic influence on the citing paper. For this purpose, we examine the effectiveness of a variety of features for determining the academic influence of a citation. By asking authors to identify the key references in their own work, we created a dataset in which citations were labeled according to their academic influence. Using automatic feature selection with supervised machine learning, we found a model for predicting academic influence that achieves good performance on this dataset using only four features. The best features, among those we evaluated, were features based on the number of times a reference is mentioned in the body of a citing paper. The performance of these features inspired us to design an influence-primed h-index (the hip-index). Unlike the conventional h-index, it weights citations by how many times a reference is mentioned. According to our experiments, the hip-index is a better indicator of researcher performance than the conventional h-index.
